Description: A box of 10 macarons with two rows of five macarons each. There are four of one color, two of another color, two of another color, and two whose sides are two different colors.

A child is on a swing. She is shown in three different positions. Position A is the highest on the left. Position B is the lowest on her path, hanging straight down from the top of the swing set. Position C is the highest to the right and is at the same height as position A.

A strip diagram labeled Bracelet is partitioned into eight equal parts. Each part is labeled one-eighth. The first part has brackets below with the label Found. The remaining 7 parts have brackets below with the label Needs to buy. Mia found one- eighth of the beads from her bracelet. Mia needs to buy seven-eighths of the beads to fix her bracelet.

There are two bar magnets side-by-side, but not touching, in an image labeled Before. The left bar magnet has a half labeled S on the left and a half labeled N on the right. The right bar magnet has a half labeled S on the left and a half labeled N on the right. Below it is an image labeled After. There are two bar magnets side-by-side, the same distance apart as the Before image. The left bar magnet has a half labeled N on the left and a half labeled S on the right. The right bar magnet has a half labeled S on the left and a half labeled N on the right.
Matter is made up of particles: atoms, molecules or ions. Matter occupies a volume in space. Matter has a mass. Matter particles are in constant motion.
AltText: A flowchart listing the characteristics of matter.

Description: Matter is defined as any substance that occupies space and has mass. A pure substance has a definite and uniform chemical composition. A mixture is a combination of two or more pure substances that retain their individual properties. A pure substance can be either an element or a compound. An element is composed of one kind of atom, for example magnesium (MG) and sulfur (S). A compound is composed of two or more kinds of atoms in a fixed ratio, for example magnesium sulfide (MG S) or water (H2 O). A mixture can be either homogeneous or heterogeneous. A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition and properties throughout, for example sea water or a metal alloy. A heterogeneous mixture has a non-uniform composition and varying properties, for example paint or salad dressing.
AltText: A flowchart showing how matter is classified into either a pure substance or a mixture, with examples.
Substance A, a red coloured powder.
Substance B, a green coloured powder.
Black powder, showing how substance A and B appear after heating.

A filter funnel is placed in the neck of a conical flask containing filtrate. There is filter paper and some residue in the funnel. Residue is defined as a substance that remains after evaporation, distillation, filtration, or any similar process.

Description: In step 1 an evaporating basin containing a sugar solution is placed on a gauze over heat. In step 2 drops of the solution from the evaporating basin are placed on a cold tile using a pipette. In step 3, the evaporating basin is left for a few days leaving the sugar to crystallize.
AltText: The steps of the crystallization process.
A close up photograph of an orange tree. The oranges are covered in ice and there are icicles on the bottom of the fruit.
A large, sealed bell jar with a smaller bell jar, containing a metal cylindrical structure, placed within it. The smaller jar and metal structure are supported on a base.
One mole of different substances is: 18 millilitres of water; 63 grams of copper; 342 grams sucrose; 58.5 grams sodium chloride; 27 grams aluminium.
Six numbered standard solutions of potassium permanganate. Each sequential solution is increasingly pigmented: 1 is clear and 6 is purple.
